title: 105_s314
content: SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget. The lists must include the fiscal year an activity first appeared, the number of employees needed, and the responsible government employee's name. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" mandates executive agencies to submit annual lists of non-inherently governmental activities to the Office of Management and Budget. The lists must include the fiscal year an activity first appeared, the required number of employees, and the contact information of the responsible government employee. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget reviews and consults with the agency head on the final list for each fiscal year, which is then made publicly available. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit annual lists of non-inherently governmental activities to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget reviews and consults with the agency head on the final list for each fiscal year, which is then made publicly available. Upon completion of the review, the head of the executive agency transmits the list to Congress and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget publishes a notice in the Federal Register. If changes occur after publication due to challenges, the agency head must make the changes available to the public and transmit them to Congress. The list of non-inherently governmental activities is made public and any changes must be promptly shared with the public and Congress. Executive agencies must use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source for activities on the list. Under subsection (c), the head of the executive agency must review activities on the list and use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance for this process. The head of the executive agency must ensure realistic and fair cost comparisons when deciding to contract with a private sector source for agency activities. This includes considering all costs such as quality assurance, technical monitoring, liability insurance, and overhead costs. SEC. 3. CHALLENGES TO THE LIST. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. An interested party is defined as a private sector source with a direct economic interest in the activity or a representative of a business/professional association. An interested party, such as a private sector source with a direct economic interest or a representative of a business/professional association, can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. The challenge must be submitted to the executive agency concerned within 30 days of publication. The head of a labor organization with members from another organization must submit a challenge to a list within 30 days of its publication. An official will decide on the challenge within 28 days and provide a written notification with the rationale for the decision. Interested parties have the right to appeal the decision. The executive agency will decide on challenges and notify the party with a written explanation. Interested parties can appeal adverse decisions to the head of the agency within 10 days. The head of the agency will then decide on the appeal within 10 days and provide a written notification with the rationale for the decision. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to executive agencies including executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments, with exceptions for the General Accounting Office, Government corporations, and nonappropriated funds instrumentalities. The General Accounting Office, Government corporations, and nonappropriated funds instrumentalities are defined in terms of their roles within executive agencies. Certain depot-level maintenance and repair for the Department of Defense is also specified. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Federal Government source" refers to any organization within an executive agency that uses Federal Government employees to perform an activity. The term "inherently governmental function" means a function that is intimately related to the public interest and requires performance by Federal Government employees, including activities that involve discretion in applying Federal Government authority or making value judgments for the Federal Government. An inherently governmental function involves discretion in applying Federal Government authority or making value judgments for the Federal Government, including decisions relating to monetary transactions and entitlements, interpretation and execution of laws to bind the United States, protect and advance national interests, and significantly affect life, liberty, or property. The term "inherently governmental function" involves decisions to protect and advance national interests, affect private persons' life, liberty, or property, and control officers or employees of the United States. It excludes functions that do not normally involve these criteria. The term "inherently governmental function" involves ultimate control over the acquisition, use, or disposition of US property, excluding functions like gathering information or ministerial tasks. The Act will be effective on October 1, 1998.
